Hi Cesar,

Evolving spiking neural networks with NEAT should not require an=
y 
major difference from evolving "regular" neural networks with NEAT.  
Th=
ere may be a few more parameters in each node or connection, but 
that is n=
ot a fundamental difference.

Note that people have evolved leaky integrato=
r neurons with NEAT.  
Also known as Continuous Time Recurrent Neural Netwo=
rks (CTRNNs), 
these networks are a kind of abstraction of spiking neural n=
etworks 
that are halfway between regular (discrete time) neural networks a=
nd 
full spiking networks.  Full spiking networks are also called "leaky 
i=
ntegrate-and-fire" networks, and are mathematically related to 
CTRNNs but =
are more biologically realistic than even CTRNNs.

You can find references =
for CTRNNs in the Discussion section of my 
dissertation.  In fact, Tyler S=
treeters "leakyNEAT" code for CTRNN-
evolving NEAT is in our Files section =
on this group:

leakyNEAT.zip 

However, I do not know of anyone who has ev=
olved full-fledged 
spiking networks with NEAT, which would be interesting.=


ken

=
>
> Hi all,
> 
> Has anyone tried NEAT with Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs)?=

> 
> I'm aware of some works in indirect genetic encoding based in
> devel=
opmental biology, which is a subject of great matter. It would
> also be in=
teresting to work with more biologically plausible neural
> networks.
> 
> =
SNNs are capable to encode information in the individual frequency 
of
> sp=
ikes and most of the work in the field is concentrated in
> computational n=
euroscience only.
> 
> I was wondering how SNN could be used with NEAT in e=
volving more
> 'realistic' neural controllers and how would that be compare=
d to 
the
> current models?
> 
> Cesar
